39367070.review:
LineWay是一款适合全年龄的益智游戏。
--优点
1.占用内存少
2.关卡数量相对较多
3.关卡难度逐渐增加
4.消磨空闲时间能力强
--缺点
界面美化问题:
1.无进入界面
2.没有设置关卡选择界面(需一关一关点)
3.最后双色关卡双色交接点移动有所卡顿(不排除硬件原因)
4.双色关卡不能保存前已完成颜色的轨迹(但可有可无)
--以上为 BeiQiao(北喬) 个人观点及建议，仅供参考。
--总而言之还是推荐此游戏。

39248792.review:
this game is where i draw the line

...

LineWay is a simple puzzle game where, presented with just a board of tiles and a starting point, you must draw a single line to connect all the tiles together. As the levels progress, several additional mechanics are thrown into the mix such as rectangular tiles and tiles that can only be filled in by wrapping around them in a circle.

The concept here isn't exactly original, nor do the majority of the levels pose a significant challenge — out of the ~50 levels, I'm going to say I had to take my time with only around 10 of them. My total playtime according to Steam is only 2.4 hours, and I am fairly certain at least a third of that was because I forgot to turn the game off while I was doing something else. Quite frankly, there are other games on Steam in the line-drawing subgenre that have been released prior, such as [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/357600/Unium/]Unium[/url], that will likely give you more bang for your buck.

That being said, the presentation of the game hit all the right notes for me. The minimalist palette is easy on the eyes, the sole music track is pleasant and unobtrusive, and sprightly sound effects play as tiles are filled in and levels are completed. It's a very soothing experience.

Overall, for a dollar, this is a nice, easygoing puzzle game that I recommend as a bite-sized relaxer.

38673122.review:
In short: The core gameplay and the minimalist visuals are okay. The rest is not.

The basic mechanic is simple and time-tested: Click on the start tile, drag the mouse to create a line, fill all tiles to complete the level. After a while new mechanics are introduced: locked tiles that require you pick up a key first, arrow tiles enforcing a direction, color changers, etc. Most of them are fine additions. I didn't really like the tiles removing or adding other tiles as they changed the level layout on the fly and it took me too long to work out how to predict which tiles would be affected.

The game starts in fullscreen. The undocumented windowed mode (Alt+Enter) doesn't allow you to resize or change the resolution and isn't remembered the next time you start the game. There are no keyboard controls, even though gameplay would lend itself to it. This being a mobile port does not excuse the lack of desktop support, as other developers manage just fine.

There is exactly one music loop which starts to grind on you around the 30 minute mark. But the really frustrating kicker is the sound it plays when you don't interact with the game. I liked staring at a new level, figuring out my path in advance. But apparently the developer thinks their players are so stupid, they need to be reminded to play the game they're looking at. So every two seconds the starting tile pulses and this really terrible *DING* sound pierces your ears. Perhaps as mockery, perhaps out of cruelty, the dev chose to include a message recommending to use headphones as the game starts. Don't. You'll have to click the tile and hold down the mouse button while you figure out the level if you want to keep your anger levels low.

And then after less than an hour the game just loops back to the first level. No end, no congratulation, nothing.

This is not a horrible trainwreck, but it just doesn't offer enough to warrant a recommendation. The price is probably fair though. If you want a much smarter game with a similar theme, a lot more content and brilliant audio design for the same price tag (on sale) check out LYNE instead.

38520757.review: LineWay is a fairly basic puzzle game. The mechanics are pretty simple, and while it did introduce some mechanics, nothing felt revolutionary. A lot of the early levels felt obvious, but some of the later ones did have me stumped for a bit. Fairly basic UI and music which works well for the game (I thought the simple music fit particularly well). It is short - took me around 50 minutes to beat - but for the price, that's fair. It isn't the most memorable puzzle game I've played, but I did enjoy it.

38300483.review: 30분이면 다 깨고 환불 받을 수 있는 갓-겜입니다.

38087370.review:
Minimalistic, simple puzzle game. 

Pros:
+ What this game does best, it constantly introduces new game mechanics. That creates a pleasant learning curve and a sense of progress. 
+ There aren't a wide variety of soundtracks, but it doesn’t get irritating. Smooth and relaxing. 
+ Sound effects and visuals are crisp and clean. 

Cons:
- Game doesn't get too challenging. You can figure out most of puzzles rather fast. You shouldn't take longer than 1-1.5h to complete whole game. 
- While the game introduces number of new mechanics, it does a poor job of combining them together into a challenging puzzle. 
- User interface non-existent. No menu, no settings. It’s literally bare boned. 

All in all, it was a pleasant and relaxing experience. It definitely could use a lot more polishing and development, but you'll get you fair share of experience from this game, which I think makes it worth it.

37946059.review:
Neat little game! It's something you can beat in less than an hour, but for $0.99 it's still a pleasant series of puzzles yknow?

The concept of the game makes it similar to games like Akin - you have to draw one continuous line through all the tiles. Simple concept, but I like that LineWay introduces new gameplay elements every 10 puzzles or so to freshen things up.

If you want a minimalist puzzle experience that's soothing, short, and sweet without getting too repetitive, this game does just the trick!

(I also just love how you connect the tiles by dragging out one continuous line, and the little sounds it makes when you let go, and the whole thing shrinks back to the original tile. It's a cute effect!)

37934957.review:
